[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The Scheduling System (SSS) defines authentication, scheduling, conflict resolution, and messaging with security and platform compatibility.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: SSS enables authentication, scheduling, conflict resolution, and messaging for administrators, mediators, and users.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 System Interfaces: SSS integrates with authentication services, scheduling databases, and OS security frameworks.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: SSS provides a role-based web UI for all system users.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: SSS runs on cloud or enterprise server infrastructure.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: SSS uses React.js frontend, Node.js backend, and PostgreSQL database.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.5 Communications Interfa: SSS ensures encrypted data exchange via TLS 1.3 and HTTPS.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: SSS manages authentication, scheduling, and system security.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: SSS supports deployment across enterprise platforms.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: SSS connects to authentication, logging, and compliance APIs.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: SSS enables authentication, scheduling, resource allocation, and secure messaging.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: SSS is designed for administrators, mediators, and users managing schedules.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.6 Limitations: SSS requires network access for authentication and scheduling operations.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 Assumptions and Dependencie: SSS relies on encryption, scheduling policies, and compliance tools.
[SUBSEC] 1.8 Definitions: Scheduling: Manages meetings and resource allocation.
Secure Authentication: Enforces login via Active Directory.

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall integrate with authentication and scheduling services.
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall provide secure scheduling and conflict resolution.

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-001: The system shall allow administrators to manage locations, resources, and scheduling rules (REQ-INTF-002).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall allow mediators to coordinate schedules, resolve conflicts, and communicate updates (REQ-INTF-002).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-003: The system shall allow users to TO-BE-DEFINED (REQ-INTF-002).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-004: The system shall authenticate users before granting scheduling access (REQ-INTF-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-005: The system shall provide users with schedule management, event notifications, and preference settings (REQ-INTF-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The system shall provide a structured UI displaying scheduled events in chronological order.

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall process scheduling and authentication within 5 seconds.

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall securely store scheduling data, user preferences, and system logs.

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall enforce secure authentication using Active Directory.

[SUBSEC] 2.7 Standards Compliance.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall enforce HTTPS encryption for data confidentiality.

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-001: The system shall ensure high security, availability, and structured scheduling.

[SEC] 3. Verification: Scheduling, authentication, messaging, and resource allocation validated.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: User guides, API documentation, and security policies.
[SEC] 5. References: Active Directory security standards, HTTPS encryption protocols, and meeting scheduling guidelines.
